docs.lead_paragraph: The health care industry is bracing for changes that could affect the costs and profits of drug companies, insurers and, ultimately, employers as the Senate prepares to reorganize with Democrats in control. The health care agenda changed radically when Senator Tom Daschle, who will be the new majority leader, said he would move ahead with patient protection legislation that had been locked up in the Senate by the Republican leadership.

headline.main: Health Care Industry Braces For Change in Senate Focus

docs.abstract: Health care industry is bracing for changes that could affect costs and profits of drug companies, insurers and employers as Senate prepares to reorganize with Democrats in control; health care agenda changes radically when Sen Tom Daschle, who will be new majority leader, says he will move ahead with patient protection legislation that has been locked up in Senate by Republican leadership; lobbyists for managed care industry begin saying that right to sue insurers for medical malpractice will be unacceptably costly unless awards are held to no more than $500,000 and cases are confined to federal courts, as Republicans have proposed; drug companies are preparing for fight over management of prescription drug benefit for elderly; Alan F Holmer, president of Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, comments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Arnitra Johnson can imagine the rush of riding one of the roller coasters at Disney World. She has never been to any of the theme parks here, but she thinks the thrill must be the same as the high she used to get from marijuana and Ecstasy. ''Ecstasy, that's the talk of the town,'' said Ms. Johnson, an 18-year-old who lived until recently in the local Covenant House, a shelter for homeless youths. ''It makes you feel good, see different colors.''

headline.main: Orlando Glitter Hides Dark Side of Young Drug Users

docs.abstract: Orlando, Fla, is battling rising drug use among its young people, particularly heroin and club drugs like Ecstasy; city is increasingly being used as US entry point by smugglers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's public hospital system, after five years of operating in the black, is poised to end its fiscal year with a $210 million deficit stemming from the very strategy adopted in recent years to assure its long-term fiscal health: moving a lot of patient care away from hospitals and into primary care clinics. The hospitals, a political hot button in the early 1990's when Rudolph W. Giuliani vowed to privatize them, have flown low on the radar screen since those efforts failed. The Health and Hospitals Corporation was forced to balance its budget with reduced help from the city. But the corporation, which serves a large proportion of the city's poor and uninsured, may present a recurring headache for the next mayor.

headline.main: After 5 Years of Fiscal Success, City Public Hospitals Face Deficit

docs.abstract: New York City Health and Hospitals Corp is poised to end fiscal year with $210 million deficit, first after five years in black; is hurt by shift of more patient care to its primary care clinics, which get lower reimbursements from Medicaid and private insurers than hospitals; is further hurt by growing percentange of immigrant patients who do not qualify for government insurance programs; seeks $87 million from Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani's executive budget (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health Risk Management, a managed care company, said yesterday that it had replaced its auditors after learning it might need to increase reserves for medical claims in a Medicaid health plan, setting off a 39 percent decline in its stock price. The shares fell $3.05, to $4.75 a share, on Nasdaq, where Health Risk led the list of percentage losers. Health Risk replaced Ernst & Young after the auditors said the company needed to raise reserves by $5 million to cover claims in the fourth quarter and first quarter, the company said. Health Risk said its fourth-quarter loss would widen to $6.52 from $5.92 and its first-quarter loss would widen to $1.32 from 85 cents if the recommendation were followed. Health Risk is based in Minneapolis.

headline.main: HEALTH RISK MANAGEMENT REPLACES ITS AUDITORS

docs.abstract: Health Risk Management, managed care company, says it has replaced its auditors, Ernst & Young, after learning it might need to increase reserves for medical claims in Medicaid health plan, setting off 39 percent decline in its stock price (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: HCA-The Healthcare Company, a leading hospital chain, agreed to sell its CCN managed care unit to the First Health Group Corporation for $195 million in cash to focus on the company's hospitals. HCA said CCN, based in San Diego, manages group health, worker's compensation and auto injury insurance benefits. HCA bought CCN in 1997 when it acquired Value Health Inc. HCA has sold Value Health units that offered disease-management, psychiatric and prescription-drug services. First Health provides group health and worker's compensation benefits for employers and management services to insurers and state Medicaid programs.

headline.main: HCA TO SELL MANAGED CARE UNIT TO FIRST HEALTH GROUP

docs.lead_paragraph: In an important First Amendment decision weighing personal privacy against the public's right to know, the Supreme Court ruled today that the press may not be held liable for publishing illegally intercepted information as long as the subject is one of ''public importance'' and the press itself did not participate in the interception. The vote was 6 to 3. The case was an appeal by two teachers' union officials in Pennsylvania whose cell phone conversation about heated contract negotiations was intercepted by an unknown person. Tapes of the conversation made their way to local radio stations and newspapers, which broadcast them and published the contents. The two officials brought a civil damage suit under the federal wiretap statute, which makes it a violation for anyone to disclose the contents of illegally intercepted communications.

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Says Press Isn't Liable For Use of Ill-Gotten Tapes

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court, in important First Amendment decision weighing personal privacy against public's right to know, rules, 6-3, that press may not be held liable for publishing illegally intercepted information as long as subject is of 'public importance' and press itself did not participate in interception; accepts appeal by Bush administration and will decide constitutionality of federal law barring use of Web for 'commercial purposes' in way that makes sexually explicit material 'harmful to minors' available to those under 17; rules, in rare interpretation of Constitution's Compensation Clause, that Congress's extension of Medicare tax to federal judgesin 1982 was constututional, but that imposition of Social Security tax in 1984 was not(M)
